section: cute_c2.h inc/cute_c2.h Go to the documentation of this file.00001 /* 00002 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 00003 Licensing information can be found at the end of the file. 00004 ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 00005 00006 cute_c2.h - v1.10 00007 00008 To create implementation (the function definitions) 00009 #define CUTE_C2_IMPLEMENTATION 00010 in *one* C/CPP file (translation unit) that includes this file 00011 00012 00013 SUMMARY 00014 00015 cute_c2 is a single-file header that implements 2D collision detection routines 00016 that test for overlap, and optionally can find the collision manifold. The 00017 manifold contains all necessary information to prevent shapes from inter- 00018 penetrating, which is useful for character controllers, general physics 00019 simulation, and user-interface programming. 00020 00021 This header implements a group of "immediate mode" functions that should be 00022 very easily adapted into pre-existing projects. 00023 00024 00025 THE IMPORTANT PARTS 00026 00027 Most of the math types in this header are for internal use. Users care about 00028 the shape types and the collision functions. 00029 00030 SHAPE TYPES: 00031 * c2Circle 00032 * c2Capsule 00033 * c2AABB 00034 * c2Ray 00035 * c2Poly 00036 00037 COLLISION FUNCTIONS (*** is a shape name from the above list): 00038 * c2***to*** - boolean YES/NO hittest 00039 * c2***to***Manifold - construct manifold to describe how shapes hit 00040 * c2GJK - runs GJK algorithm to find closest point pair between two shapes 00041 * c2TOI - computes the time of impact between two shapes, useful for sweeping shapes, or doing shape casts 00042 * c2MakePoly - Runs convex hull algorithm and computes normals on input point-set 00043 * c2Collided - generic version of c2***to*** funcs 00044 * c2Collide - generic version of c2***to***Manifold funcs 00045 * c2CastRay - generic version of c2Rayto*** funcs 00046 00047 The rest of the header is more or less for internal use. Here is an example of 00048 making some shapes and testing for collision: 00049 00050 c2Circle c; 00051 c.p = position; 00052 c.r = radius; 00053 00054 c2Capsule cap; 00055 cap.a = first_endpoint; 00056 cap.b = second_endpoint; 00057 cap.r = radius; 00058 00059 int hit = c2CircletoCapsule(c, cap); 00060 if (hit) 00061 { 00062 handle collision here... 00063 } 00064 00065 For more code examples and tests please see: 00066 https://github.com/RandyGaul/cute_header/tree/master/examples_cute_gl_and_c2 00067 00068 Here is a past discussion thread on this header: 00069 https://www.reddit.com/r/gamedev/comments/5tqyey/tinyc2_2d_collision_detection_library_in_c/ 00070 00071 Here is a very nice repo containing various tests and examples using SFML for rendering: 00072 https://github.com/sro5h/tinyc2-tests 00073 00074 00075 FEATURES 00076 00077 * Circles, capsules, AABBs, rays and convex polygons are supported 00078 * Fast boolean only result functions (hit yes/no) 00079 * Slghtly slower manifold generation for collision normals + depths +points 00080 * GJK implementation (finds closest points for disjoint pairs of shapes) 00081 * Shape casts/sweeps with c2TOI function (time of impact) 00082 * Robust 2D convex hull generator 00083 * Lots of correctly implemented and tested 2D math routines 00084 * Implemented in portable C, and is readily portable to other languages 00085 * Generic c2Collide, c2Collided and c2CastRay function (can pass in any shape type) 00086 * Extensive examples at: https://github.com/RandyGaul/cute_headers/tree/master/examples_cute_gl_and_c2 00087 00088 00089 Revision History 00090 00091 1.0 (02/13/2017) initial release 00092 1.01 (02/13/2017) const crusade, minor optimizations, capsule degen 00093 1.02 (03/21/2017) compile fixes for c on more compilers 00094 1.03 (09/15/2017) various bugfixes and quality of life changes to manifolds 00095 1.04 (03/25/2018) fixed manifold bug in c2CircletoAABBManifold 00096 1.05 (11/01/2018) added c2TOI (time of impact) for shape cast/sweep test 00097 1.06 (08/23/2019) C2_*** types to C2_TYPE_***, and CUTE_C2_API 00098 1.07 (10/19/2019) Optimizations to c2TOI - breaking change to c2GJK API 00099 1.08 (12/22/2019) Remove contact point + normal from c2TOI, removed feather 00100 radius from c2GJK, fixed various bugs in capsule to poly 00101 manifold, did a pass on all docs 00102 1.09 (07/27/2019) Added c2Inflate - to inflate/deflate shapes for c2TOI 00103 1.10 (02/05/2022) Implemented GJK-Raycast for c2TOI (from E. Catto's Box2D) 00104 00105 00106 Contributors 00107 00108 Plastburk 1.01 - const pointers pull request 00109 mmozeiko 1.02 - 3 compile bugfixes 00110 felipefs 1.02 - 3 compile bugfixes 00111 seemk 1.02 - fix branching bug in c2Collide 00112 sro5h 1.02 - bug reports for multiple manifold funcs 00113 sro5h 1.03 - work involving quality of life fixes for manifolds 00114 Wizzard033 1.06 - C2_*** types to C2_TYPE_***, and CUTE_C2_API 00115 Tyler Glaeil 1.08 - Lots of bug reports and disussion on capsules + TOIs 00116 00117 00118 DETAILS/ADVICE 00119 00120 BROAD PHASE 00121 00122 This header does not implement a broad-phase, and instead concerns itself with 00123 the narrow-phase. This means this header just checks to see if two individual 00124 shapes are touching, and can give information about how they are touching. 00125 00126 Very common 2D broad-phases are tree and grid approaches. Quad trees are good 00127 for static geometry that does not move much if at all. Dynamic AABB trees are 00128 good for general purpose use, and can handle moving objects very well. Grids 00129 are great and are similar to quad trees. 00130 00131 If implementing a grid it can be wise to have each collideable grid cell hold 00132 an integer. This integer refers to a 2D shape that can be passed into the 00133 various functions in this header. The shape can be transformed from "model" 00134 space to "world" space using c2x -- a transform struct. In this way a grid 00135 can be implemented that holds any kind of convex shape (that this header 00136 supports) while conserving memory with shape instancing. 00137 00138 NUMERIC ROBUSTNESS 00139 00140 Many of the functions in cute c2 use `c2GJK`, an implementation of the GJK 00141 algorithm. Internally GJK computes signed area values, and these values are 00142 very numerically sensitive to large shapes. This means the GJK function will 00143 break down if input shapes are too large or too far away from the origin. 00144 00145 In general it is best to compute collision detection on small shapes very 00146 close to the origin. One trick is to keep your collision information numerically 00147 very tiny, and simply scale it up when rendering to the appropriate size. 00148 00149 For reference, if your shapes are all AABBs and contain a width and height 00150 of somewhere between 1.0f and 10.0f, everything will be fine. However, once 00151 your shapes start approaching a width/height of 100.0f to 1000.0f GJK can 00152 start breaking down. 00153 00154 This is a complicated topic, so feel free to ask the author for advice here. 00155 00156 Here is an example demonstrating this problem with two large AABBs: 00157 https://github.com/RandyGaul/cute_headers/issues/160 00158 00159 Please email at my address with any questions or comments at: 00160 author's last name followed by 1748 at gmail 00161 */ 00162 00163 #if !defined(CUTE_C2_H) 00164 00165 // this can be adjusted as necessary, but is highly recommended to be kept at 8. 00166 // higher numbers will incur quite a bit of memory overhead, and convex shapes 00167 // over 8 verts start to just look like spheres, which can be implicitly rep- 00168 // resented as a point + radius. usually tools that generate polygons should be 00169 // constructed so they do not output polygons with too many verts. 00170 // Note: polygons in cute_c2 are all *convex*. 00171 #define C2_MAX_POLYGON_VERTS 8 00172 00173 // 2d vector 00174 typedef struct c2v 00175 { 00176 float x; 00177 float y; 00178 } c2v; 00179 00180 // 2d rotation composed of cos/sin pair for a single angle 00181 // We use two floats as a small optimization to avoid computing sin/cos unnecessarily 00182 typedef struct c2r 00183 { 00184 float c; 00185 float s; 00186 } c2r; 00187 00188 // 2d rotation matrix 00189 typedef struct c2m 00190 { 00191 c2v x; 00192 c2v y; 00193 } c2m; 00194 00195 // 2d transformation "x" 00196 // These are used especially for c2Poly when a c2Poly is passed to a function. 00197 // Since polygons are prime for "instancing" a c2x transform can be used to 00198 // transform a polygon from local space to world space. In functions that take 00199 // a c2x pointer (like c2PolytoPoly), these pointers can be NULL, which represents 00200 // an identity transformation and assumes the verts inside of c2Poly are already 00201 // in world space. 00202 typedef struct c2x 00203 { 00204 c2v p; 00205 c2r r; 00206 } c2x; 00207 00208 // 2d halfspace (aka plane, aka line) 00209 typedef struct c2h 00210 { 00211 c2v n; // normal, normalized 00212 float d; // distance to origin from plane, or ax + by = d 00213 } c2h; 00214 00215 typedef struct c2Circle 00216 { 00217 c2v p; 00218 float r; 00219 } c2Circle; 00220 00221 typedef struct c2AABB 00222 { 00223 c2v min; 00224 c2v max; 00225 } c2AABB; 00226 00227 // a capsule is defined as a line segment (from a to b) and radius r 00228 typedef struct c2Capsule 00229 { 00230 c2v a; 00231 c2v b; 00232 float r; 00233 } c2Capsule; 00234 00235 typedef struct c2Poly 00236 { 00237 int count; 00238 c2v verts[C2_MAX_POLYGON_VERTS]; 00239 c2v norms[C2_MAX_POLYGON_VERTS]; 00240 } c2Poly; 00241 00242 // IMPORTANT: 00243 // Many algorithms in this file are sensitive to the magnitude of the 00244 // ray direction (c2Ray::d). It is highly recommended to normalize the 00245 // ray direction and use t to specify a distance. Please see this link 00246 // for an in-depth explanation: https://github.com/RandyGaul/cute_headers/issues/30 00247 typedef struct c2Ray 00248 { 00249 c2v p; // position 00250 c2v d; // direction (normalized) 00251 float t; // distance along d from position p to find endpoint of ray 00252 } c2Ray; 00253 00254 typedef struct c2Raycast 00255 { 00256 float t; // time of impact 00257 c2v n; // normal of surface at impact (unit length) 00258 } c2Raycast; 00259 00260 // position of impact p = ray.p + ray.d * raycast.t 00261 #define c2Impact(ray, t) c2Add(ray.p, c2Mulvs(ray.d, t)) 00262 00263 // contains all information necessary to resolve a collision, or in other words 00264 // this is the information needed to separate shapes that are colliding. Doing 00265 // the resolution step is *not* included in cute_c2. 00266 typedef struct c2Manifold 00267 { 00268 int count; 00269 float depths[2]; 00270 c2v contact_points[2]; 00271 00272 // always points from shape A to shape B (first and second shapes passed into 00273 // any of the c2***to***Manifold functions) 00274 c2v n; 00275 } c2Manifold; 00276 00277 // This define allows exporting/importing of the header to a dynamic library. 00278 // Here's an example. 00279 // #define CUTE_C2_API extern "C" __declspec(dllexport) 00280 #if !defined(CUTE_C2_API) 00281 # define CUTE_C2_API 00282 #endif 00283 00284 // boolean collision detection 00285 // these versions are faster than the manifold versions, but only give a YES/NO result 00286 CUTE_C2_API int c2CircletoCircle(c2Circle A, c2Circle B); 00287 CUTE_C2_API int c2CircletoAABB(c2Circle A, c2AABB B); 00288 CUTE_C2_API int c2CircletoCapsule(c2Circle A, c2Capsule B); 00289 CUTE_C2_API int c2AABBtoAABB(c2AABB A, c2AABB B); 00290 CUTE_C2_API int c2AABBtoCapsule(c2AABB A, c2Capsule B); 00291 CUTE_C2_API int c2CapsuletoCapsule(c2Capsule A, c2Capsule B); 00292 CUTE_C2_API int c2CircletoPoly(c2Circle A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx); 00293 CUTE_C2_API int c2AABBtoPoly(c2AABB A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx); 00294 CUTE_C2_API int c2CapsuletoPoly(c2Capsule A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx); 00295 CUTE_C2_API int c2PolytoPoly(const c2Poly* A, const c2x* ax, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx); 00296 00297 // ray operations 00298 // output is placed into the c2Raycast struct, which represents the hit location 00299 // of the ray. the out param contains no meaningful information if these funcs 00300 // return 0 00301 CUTE_C2_API int c2RaytoCircle(c2Ray A, c2Circle B, c2Raycast* out); 00302 CUTE_C2_API int c2RaytoAABB(c2Ray A, c2AABB B, c2Raycast* out); 00303 CUTE_C2_API int c2RaytoCapsule(c2Ray A, c2Capsule B, c2Raycast* out); 00304 CUTE_C2_API int c2RaytoPoly(c2Ray A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx_ptr, c2Raycast* out); 00305 00306 // manifold generation 00307 // These functions are (generally) slower than the boolean versions, but will compute one 00308 // or two points that represent the plane of contact. This information is usually needed 00309 // to resolve and prevent shapes from colliding. If no collision occured the count member 00310 // of the manifold struct is set to 0. 00311 CUTE_C2_API void c2CircletoCircleManifold(c2Circle A, c2Circle B, c2Manifold* m); 00312 CUTE_C2_API void c2CircletoAABBManifold(c2Circle A, c2AABB B, c2Manifold* m); 00313 CUTE_C2_API void c2CircletoCapsuleManifold(c2Circle A, c2Capsule B, c2Manifold* m); 00314 CUTE_C2_API void c2AABBtoAABBManifold(c2AABB A, c2AABB B, c2Manifold* m); 00315 CUTE_C2_API void c2AABBtoCapsuleManifold(c2AABB A, c2Capsule B, c2Manifold* m); 00316 CUTE_C2_API void c2CapsuletoCapsuleManifold(c2Capsule A, c2Capsule B, c2Manifold* m); 00317 CUTE_C2_API void c2CircletoPolyManifold(c2Circle A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx, c2Manifold* m); 00318 CUTE_C2_API void c2AABBtoPolyManifold(c2AABB A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx, c2Manifold* m); 00319 CUTE_C2_API void c2CapsuletoPolyManifold(c2Capsule A, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx, c2Manifold* m); 00320 CUTE_C2_API void c2PolytoPolyManifold(const c2Poly* A, const c2x* ax, const c2Poly* B, const c2x* bx, c2Manifold* m); 00321 00322 typedef enum 00323 { 00324 C2_TYPE_NONE, 00325 C2_TYPE_CIRCLE, 00326 C2_TYPE_AABB, 00327 C2_TYPE_CAPSULE, 00328 C2_TYPE_POLY 00329 } C2_TYPE; 00330 00331 // This struct is only for advanced usage of the c2GJK function. See comments inside of the 00332 // c2GJK function for more details. 00333 typedef struct c2GJKCache 00334 { 00335 float metric; 00336 int count; 00337 int iA[3]; 00338 int iB[3]; 00339 float div; 00340 } c2GJKCache; 00341 00342 // This is an advanced function, intended to be used by people who know what they're doing. 00343 // 00344 // Runs the GJK algorithm to find closest points, returns distance between closest points. 00345 // outA and outB can be NULL, in this case only distance is returned. ax_ptr and bx_ptr 00346 // can be NULL, and represent local to world transformations for shapes A and B respectively. 00347 // use_radius will apply radii for capsules and circles (if set to false, spheres are 00348 // treated as points and capsules are treated as line segments i.e. rays). The cache parameter 00349 // should be NULL, as it is only for advanced usage (unless you know what you're doing, then 00350 // go ahead and use it). iterations is an optional parameter. 00351 // 00352 // IMPORTANT NOTE: 00353 // The GJK function is sensitive to large shapes, since it internally will compute signed area 00354 // values. `c2GJK` is called throughout cute c2 in many ways, so try to make sure all of your 00355 // collision shapes are not gigantic. For example, try to keep the volume of all your shapes 00356 // less than 100.0f. If you need large shapes, you should use tiny collision geometry for all 00357 // cute c2 function, and simply render the geometry larger on-screen by scaling it up. 00358 CUTE_C2_API float c2GJK(const void* A, C2_TYPE typeA, const c2x* ax_ptr, const void* B, C2_TYPE typeB, const c2x* bx_ptr, c2v* outA, c2v* outB, int use_radius, int* iterations, c2GJKCache* cache); 00359 00360 // Stores results of a time of impact calculation done by `c2TOI`. 00361 typedef struct c2TOIResult 00362 { 00363 int hit; // 1 if shapes were touching at the TOI, 0 if they never hit. 00364 float toi; // The time of impact between two shapes. 00365 c2v n; // Surface normal from shape A to B at the time of impact. 00366 c2v p; // Point of contact between shapes A and B at time of impact. 00367 int iterations; // Number of iterations the solver underwent. 00368 } c2TOIResult; 00369 00370 // This is an advanced function, intended to be used by people who know what they're doing. 00371 // 00372 // Computes the time of impact from shape A and shape B. The velocity of each shape is provided 00373 // by vA and vB respectively. The shapes are *not* allowed to rotate over time. The velocity is 00374 // assumed to represent the change in motion from time 0 to time 1, and so the return value will 00375 // be a number from 0 to 1. To move each shape to the colliding configuration, multiply vA and vB 00376 // each by the return value. ax_ptr and bx_ptr are optional parameters to transforms for each shape, 00377 // and are typically used for polygon shapes to transform from model to world space. Set these to 00378 // NULL to represent identity transforms. iterations is an optional parameter. use_radius 00379 // will apply radii for capsules and circles (if set to false, spheres are treated as points and 00380 // capsules are treated as line segments i.e. rays). 00381 // 00382 // IMPORTANT NOTE: 00383 // The c2TOI function can be used to implement a "swept character controller", but it can be 00384 // difficult to do so. Say we compute a time of impact with `c2TOI` and move the shapes to the 00385 // time of impact, and adjust the velocity by zeroing out the velocity along the surface normal. 00386 // If we then call `c2TOI` again, it will fail since the shapes will be considered to start in 00387 // a colliding configuration. There are many styles of tricks to get around this problem, and 00388 // all of them involve giving the next call to `c2TOI` some breathing room. It is recommended 00389 // to use some variation of the following algorithm: 00390 // 00391 // 1. Call c2TOI. 00392 // 2. Move the shapes to the TOI. 00393 // 3. Slightly inflate the size of one, or both, of the shapes so they will be intersecting. 00394 // The purpose is to make the shapes numerically intersecting, but not visually intersecting. 00395 // Another option is to call c2TOI with slightly deflated shapes. 00396 // See the function `c2Inflate` for some more details. 00397 // 4. Compute the collision manifold between the inflated shapes (for example, use c2PolytoPolyManifold). 00398 // 5. Gently push the shapes apart. This will give the next call to c2TOI some breathing room. 00399 CUTE_C2_API c2TOIResult c2TOI(const void* A, C2_TYPE typeA, const c2x* ax_ptr, c2v vA, const void* B, C2_TYPE typeB, const c2x* bx_ptr, c2v vB, int use_radius); 00400 00401 // Inflating a shape. 00402 // 00403 // This is useful to numerically grow or shrink a polytope. For example, when calling 00404 // a time of impact function it can be good to use a slightly smaller shape. Then, once 00405 // both shapes are moved to the time of impact a collision manifold can be made from the 00406 // slightly larger (and now overlapping) shapes. 00407 // 00408 // IMPORTANT NOTE 00409 // Inflating a shape with sharp corners can cause those corners to move dramatically. 00410 // Deflating a shape can avoid this problem, but deflating a very small shape can invert 00411 // the planes and result in something that is no longer convex. Make sure to pick an 00412 // appropriately small skin factor, for example 1.0e-6f. 00413 CUTE_C2_API void c2Inflate(void* shape, C2_TYPE type, float skin_factor); 00414 00415 // Computes 2D convex hull. Will not do anything if less than two verts supplied. If 00416 // more than C2_MAX_POLYGON_VERTS are supplied extras are ignored. 00417 CUTE_C2_API int c2Hull(c2v* verts, int count); 00418 CUTE_C2_API void c2Norms(c2v* verts, c2v* norms, int count); 00419 00420 // runs c2Hull and c2Norms, assumes p->verts and p->count are both set to valid values 00421 CUTE_C2_API void c2MakePoly(c2Poly* p); 00422 00423 // Generic collision detection routines, useful for games that want to use some poly- 00424 // morphism to write more generic-styled code. Internally calls various above functions. 00425 // For AABBs/Circles/Capsules ax and bx are ignored. For polys ax and bx can define 00426 // model to world transformations (for polys only), or be NULL for identity transforms. 00427 CUTE_C2_API int c2Collided(const void* A, const c2x* ax, C2_TYPE typeA, const void* B, const c2x* bx, C2_TYPE typeB); 00428 CUTE_C2_API void c2Collide(const void* A, const c2x* ax, C2_TYPE typeA, const void* B, const c2x* bx, C2_TYPE typeB, c2Manifold* m); 00429 CUTE_C2_API int c2CastRay(c2Ray A, const void* B, const c2x* bx, C2_TYPE typeB, c2Raycast* out); 00430 00431 #ifdef _MSC_VER 00432 #define C2_INLINE __forceinline 00433 #else 00434 #define C2_INLINE inline __attribute__((always_inline)) 00435 #endif 00436 00437 // adjust these primitives as seen fit 00438 #include <string.h> // memcpy 00439 #include <math.h> 00440 #define c2Sin(radians) sinf(radians) 00441 #define c2Cos(radians) cosf(radians) 00442 #define c2Sqrt(a) sqrtf(a) 00443 #define c2Min(a, b) ((a) < (b) ? (a) : (b)) 00444 #define c2Max(a, b) ((a) > (b) ? (a) : (b)) 00445 #define c2Abs(a) ((a) < 0 ? -(a) : (a)) 00446 #define c2Clamp(a, lo, hi) c2Max(lo, c2Min(a, hi)) 00447 C2_INLINE void c2SinCos(float radians, float* s, float* c) { *c = c2Cos(radians); *s = c2Sin(radians); } 00448 #define c2Sign(a) (a < 0 ? -1.0f : 1.0f) 00449 00450 // The rest of the functions in the header-only portion are all for internal use 00451 // and use the author's personal naming conventions. It is recommended to use one's 00452 // own math library instead of the one embedded here in cute_c2, but for those 00453 // curious or interested in trying it out here's the details: 00454 00455 // The Mul functions are used to perform multiplication. x stands for transform, 00456 // v stands for vector, s stands for scalar, r stands for rotation, h stands for 00457 // halfspace and T stands for transpose.For example c2MulxvT stands for "multiply 00458 // a transform with a vector, and transpose the transform". 00459 00460 // vector ops 00461 C2_INLINE c2v c2V(float x, float y) { c2v a; a.x = x; a.y = y; return a; } 00462 C2_INLINE c2v c2Add(c2v a, c2v b) { a.x += b.x; a.y += b.y; return a; } 00463 C2_INLINE c2v c2Sub(c2v a, c2v b) { a.x -= b.x; a.y -= b.y; return a; } 00464 C2_INLINE float c2Dot(c2v a, c2v b) { return a.x * b.x + a.y * b.y; } 00465 C2_INLINE c2v c2Mulvs(c2v a, float b) { a.x *= b; a.y *= b; return a; } 00466 C2_INLINE c2v c2Mulvv(c2v a, c2v b) { a.x *= b.x; a.y *= b.y; return a; } 00467 C2_INLINE c2v c2Div(c2v a, float b) { return c2Mulvs(a, 1.0f / b); } 00468 C2_INLINE c2v c2Skew(c2v a) { c2v b; b.x = -a.y; b.y = a.x; return b; } 00469 C2_INLINE c2v c2CCW90(c2v a) { c2v b; b.x = a.y; b.y = -a.x; return b; } 00470 C2_INLINE float c2Det2(c2v a, c2v b) { return a.x * b.y - a.y * b.x; } 00471 C2_INLINE c2v c2Minv(c2v a, c2v b) { return c2V(c2Min(a.x, b.x), c2Min(a.y, b.y)); } 00472 C2_INLINE c2v c2Maxv(c2v a, c2v b) { return c2V(c2Max(a.x, b.x), c2Max(a.y, b.y)); } 00473 C2_INLINE c2v c2Clampv(c2v a, c2v lo, c2v hi) { return c2Maxv(lo, c2Minv(a, hi)); } 00474 C2_INLINE c2v c2Absv(c2v a) { return c2V(c2Abs(a.x), c2Abs(a.y)); } 00475 C2_INLINE float c2Hmin(c2v a) { return c2Min(a.x, a.y); } 00476 C2_INLINE float c2Hmax(c2v a) { return c2Max(a.x, a.y); } 00477 C2_INLINE float c2Len(c2v a) { return c2Sqrt(c2Dot(a, a)); } 00478 C2_INLINE c2v c2Norm(c2v a) { return c2Div(a, c2Len(a)); } 00479 C2_INLINE c2v c2SafeNorm(c2v a) { float sq = c2Dot(a, a); return sq ? c2Div(a, c2Len(a)) : c2V(0, 0); } 00480 C2_INLINE c2v c2Neg(c2v a) { return c2V(-a.x, -a.y); } 00481 C2_INLINE c2v c2Lerp(c2v a, c2v b, float t) { return c2Add(a, c2Mulvs(c2Sub(b, a), t)); } 00482 C2_INLINE int c2Parallel(c2v a, c2v b, float kTol) 00483 { 00484 float k = c2Len(a) / c2Len(b); return r; } 00492 C2_INLINE c2r c2RotIdentity(void) { c2r r; r.c = 1.0f; r.s = 0; return r; } 00493 C2_INLINE c2v c2RotX(c2r r) { return c2V(r.c, r.s); } 00494 C2_INLINE c2v c2RotY(c2r r) { return c2V(-r.s, r.c);
